messageBody:
>>In fact, you are saying that we should leave the fields accessible until
the
>>tests scream that they would prefer a getter/setter ?

>>I do understand that the public (or protected) field is much simpler to
test.
>>But that goes against everything I read in OOA/D/P books lately :)

>>Thanks,
>>Francois

No, the fields should not be accessible outside the class unless the class
is a
very simple record/structure type of object such as the Point object in AWT.

There are two schools of thought regarding getter/setters. The first says
don't use
them inside the class if they are simple but provide them if necessary to
the outside world.
The second says always use them inside the class and make them accessable to
the outside
world on a need-to-know basis. There are advantages to both.

What I said was "Don't provide setter/getter unless a test you are writing
says
you need them." For example, if my object gets its values at creation time
and those
values never change, I don't need to provide a public setter. For example
the File object
gets a name at creation and provides a getName() method but no setName()
method.
But notice that the File object has some setters for attributes that might
change
during its lifetime such as setReadonly().

Do the simplest thing possible. Don't add methods to an object until you
need them.
